metadata.title: Getting started with Bitcoin data on Kaggle with Python and BigQuery | by Andras Novoszath | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Getting started with Bitcoin data on Kaggle with Python and BigQuery
metadata.description: In my previous post, I examined the usability of Python on studying BigQuery data on Kaggle. There, I concluded that, as for now, we could not avoid using BigQuery more extensively than I initially…

all_paragraphs: In my previous post, I examined the usability of Python on studying BigQuery data on Kaggle. There, I concluded that, as for now, we could not avoid using BigQuery more extensively than I initially assumed.
(This post is part of a series about analyzing BigQuery blockchain data with Python. For an overview of the project and the posts, see this link.)

In this post, I show a simple and straightforward way to run a query of the BigQuery Bitcoin dataset on Kaggle with the help of pandas and Google’s bigquery Python module. You can see and fork the notebook based on which I wrote this post, and you can read more about the dataset on its BigQuery page.

While there are other ways to access Bitcoin data, Google’s BigQuery dataset collection is the most exhaustive and up-to-date data source on Bitcoin, and it also incorporates data on further cryptocurrencies. On the other hand, using BigQuery through the Google Cloud Platform is an entirely separate set of skills that you need to master to start the analysis. Compared to this, using Kaggle can give you a quick headstart, although — as I pointed out in that previous post — you do need to know some BigQuery SQL. Furthermore, through Google Cloud, in the free plan, you can process only 1TB of data a month, while using Kaggle’s license provides you 5TBs of processing power.

First, I will introduce the BigQuery Client object, which we will use to access the data. With the help of this object, we will get some insights into the high-level structure of BigQuery datasets. Following that, we will write a simple query to access the Bitcoin data.

Because the Bitcoin dataset is vast and because using BigQuery can be very costly (both in terms of memory usage and time), we will also assess the size of the query and the resulting dataframe. While it is not our main focus here, in the end, we will generate a few plots with pandas.

Here we use Google’s official Python library and specifically its bigquery module. After importing the library, we initialize a Client object, which will be our primary tool to access and handle the data.
Because we will often examine the objects we create and use, we create a helper function to simplify this process.

We try it out on our client object. This gives us a sense of what kind of other objects it works with (e.g. 'table', 'database', 'schema', 'model', 'rows', 'job') and what are the operations it supposed to execute (e.g. 'list', 'get', 'update', 'delete').
(If you are interested in the details of the client object, you can read more about it in its documentation or its API description)
To understand the following steps, it helps if we start with an overview image.
(The image is from Kaggle’s tutorial. It uses the example of the Hackernews dataset, but its logic also applies here).

The structure is relatively straightforward. A client can have multiple projects which have its datasets consisting of various tables. We have already created a client object, so, in this section, we continue with the following steps:
While demonstrating these steps, we will frequently examine the attributes of the objects we created. I hope this will make this process more understandable and reproducible.

Besides merely accessing the data, whenever we want to do something else, or whenever we need some information beforehand, we need to be able to navigate ourselves around among datasets and tables. The following steps show us the fundamentals way to do this.
One of the primary use of the client object is to get information about the data objects we try to access. For example, looking for the term 'list', our function returns the following attributes.
In line with our intentions, we will use list_tables and list_rows.
(We could also try to list datasets, but the Kaggle license does not allow this). We can find the dataset name listed on its page)

First, we want to list tables. Before any of this, however, we need to define a project through which we access a BigQuery dataset. Because we work through Kaggle’s license, we use the ‘bigquery-public-data’ project. The name of the dataset is ‘crypto_bitcoin’.
We pass these parameters to the list_tables method, which, in turn, returns an iterator.
To have a better look, we list the attributes of the first item it returns.
This list shows the attributes of the table objects in the dataset. Based on it, we will use the table_id attribute, which will return the name of the tables in the dataset.
Let’s examine the transactions table. We can do this, again, through the Client object. Here we list the table-related client attributes and methods.
From among these, we use the get_table method. Doing this will create a reference to the table which we can access to examine its internals.
First, we examine the table’s schema.

This list shows information about the table’s columns, like its name and its data type. We can also see that the inputs and outputs table are themselves include further SchmeaField objects, which shows that there are additional tables nested in the column.
For a better understanding, we list out the first five rows of the table and convert it into a pandas dataframe.

Finally, we take a peek on the outputs value of the first. Because–as we noticed–it is a nested table, the content of that 'cell' is the corresponding output-related information of the first transaction.

At this point, we arrived at the limits of the operations of the BigQuery client object. It is useful for having a sense of the examined dataset and the tables, but for doing anything more substantial, we need to run actual SQL queries.

Let’s say we are interested in the frequency and value of bitcoin transactions during September 2017. We would like to have an identifier of the transactions, their time (at least approximately), and the counts and values of inputs and outputs.
The following SQL query does just that.
This is a straightforward query, but let’s do some explanation:
FROM: It accesses the transactons table from the crypto_bitcoin dataset and through the bigquery-public-data project.

WHERE: It filters the data to show only records where the block timestamp falls on September 2017. (As this post explains, bitcoin transactions do not have their timestamps as they are bundled together in blocks, so this is the nearest thing we can use as a time indicator)

Because of the resource limitation with which we need to work, it is a good practice to estimate the query size before we run it. We can do this by turning on the dry run job configuration parameter. For this, we wrote a helper function.

This query then will need to process around 53 GBs of data. As we work through Kaggle’s license, we have a 5TB monthly budget, so that we will be fine. However, this is a limited query and, for example, running a SELECT * on the transactions table would need to process 1TB of data.

Now, it is time to run the query. Because, by default, a job is limited to 1GBs to prevent the accidentally processing of too much data, we need to set a new limit manually. We do this by passing a maximum_bytes_billed job configuration parameter when initializing a BigQuery QueryJobConfig object.
After that, we pass this object to the client object's query method.
The next step is to get the results of the job. We also convert it into a pandas dataframe as it is the form in which we would like to continue to work with the data after this step.
(A note for those who are thinking about running this code: this single step takes around 15 minutes to run.)
Having the data in dataframe format is a good milestone. Still, we also would like to assess the size of the result.
The resulting dataframe is quite big, more than 7 million lines, and occupies almost 2.5 GBytes, which-depending on the intended work-can impact processing time.

However, as the detailed view shows, most of the size comes from three columns: hash, input_value, and output_value. While we will not do this here, if needed, and if it does not interfere with our analytical goals, we can reduce the object size by uncasting the numerical values and converting the hash information into a categorical.
Nevertheless, for later use, we can save the dataframe into a csv, allowing us next time to avoid querying the data from the cloud.

Finally, let’s do some basic data visualizations. As we have input and output values and counts for the transactions and a block timestamp, we can easily examine how they changed in time and whether there is an apparent temporal pattern in their value. (The following is a selection, you can find all the plots in the notebook)
To do this, however, we need to convert the timestamp into pandas datetime format.
Here we plot the values of the actual transaction output values on the timestamp of their blocks.

As this is a too finely grained plot, it is hard to see overall patterns, but it does show some outliers events. For example, from around 12 September, output values started high and decreased gradually during the following days. During this month, the Bitcoin price experienced a significant fall, for example, on the 14th, its value dropped by more than $500.
The next plot shows us how the total output values were distributed on the days of the week.

Based on the plot, Tuesdays and Thursdays had more transaction outputs, and Sunday had the least. Especially the Sunday value seems to follow an unsurprising pattern (i.e., people trade less during weekends). However, to give sense to the other values, we might want to remove outliers (e.g., 14 September was a Thursday).
The last plot works similarly to the previous one; only it shows the distribution between the hours of the day.

The distribution seems to tell us that Bitcoin transactions had the least output value between the 1800–0100 period and the highest around 0800–1000 and around 1300–1400. Nevertheless, the plot uses raw timestamp data without any handling of timezones, so, for a better understanding, we should also take into account geographical differences.

As we saw, after we have successfully pulled the data, to generate plots with python is easy. However, to make the plots meaningful, we do need to dive more into the data dimensions specs and to conduct preprocessing.

To sum it up, in this post, we reviewed a simple way to get started with analyzing Bitcoin data on Kaggle with the help of Python and BigQuery. In particular, we introduced the Client object from Google’s bigquery Python module and showed how we could use it to get around datasets and tables. We also wrote a simple SQL query and estimated its size. We pulled the data, transformed it into a dataframe, saved it, and generated some plots from it.

One aim of this post to help others to get into blockchain analytics, so if anything is unclear, or if you miss anything from here, let me know in the comments. And, again, feel free to fork the kernel on Kaggle and use it for your research.
Data Scientist & Technical Content Writer. Writing about blockchain, Web3.0, data science, machine learning.
